data.description: RU a new? Have you heard about Douglass, historically known as the women's college at Rutgers? RU looking for a supportive community that will help you hit the ground running and get the most of your time here? Come check out Douglass where we focus on women's leadership by providing special opportunities for you to build your skills and surround yourself with students and staff who are passionate about social justice and centering women's lived experiences.  Meet new and current Douglass students and staff and hear about the opportunities and experiences that will enhance your college journey. From social events like International Women's Day to internship and research opportunities, Douglass enhances all majors and helps you build your resume and connections. Don't miss food and Douglass swag!!   Image and Media Release By attending this event, you acknowledge and agree that Rutgers University may photograph, record, or otherwise capture your image, and/or voice at this event. You grant Rutgers the unrestricted right to use, reproduce, publish, and distribute these sound, still, or moving images in any medium for educational, promotional, advertising, or other purposes aligned with the University’s mission. All rights to these materials will belong to Rutgers University. Please let our photographer or videographer know if you do not want your image taken at the event.

data.description: BEAT will take a field trip to NYU Tandon in Brooklyn for a talk will about using data and coding to simulate real and fantasy transit lines. It will be hosted by Sunny Ng, software engineer with the MTA, in addition to the Transit Techies group at NYU Tandon's Center for Urban Science and Progress. One of the featured guests is the developer of the popular game Subway Builder.Where: 370 Jay St, Brooklyn, NY 11201 When: Wednesday, January 28, 2026. Leave New Brunswick station at 4:30 pm, maybe get dinner, arrive at event at 6:30 pm, runs until 8:30 pm, get back to New Brunswick around 10:30 pm (all times are approximate)
data.name: Field Trip to Transit Techies talk at NYU Tandon
data.organizationName: Bloustein Enthusiasts and Advocates for Transportation

data.description: Every 1st and 3rd Thursday of each month! We start again on 2/5/26!  Join us for a creative space where students can explore self-expression through art. Each session offers guided prompts as well as the freedom to create in your own style and medium—whether drawing, painting, writing, or any other form of artistic expression. This group encourages open dialogue, reflection, and connection while using art as a tool for self-discovery and communication.

data.description: Treat yourself this Valentine’s season! Join us in Ludwig for a night dedicated entirely to self-love and self-care. Take a break from the books and get creative at our DIY craft stations:   Bracelet Making: String together a custom bracelet with colorful and festive pieces.   Soap-Making: Craft Your Own Soothing Soaps. Think herb-infused scents and colors.   Tote Bag Creation: Design a personalized bag using puff paint, fabric paint, and iron-on patches.   Whether you're coming with friends or looking for a solo mid-week reset, come celebrate the most important person in your life: you!
data.location: Kathleen W. Ludwig Global Village Living Learning Center
data.name: Self-Love-a-Thon
data.organizationName: Honors College

data.description: The Douglass-Honors College Community presents... Learn to Crochet II: The DRC Red Pine Granny Square Unplug and get hands-on! Join us for a workshop focused on the art of crochet. You’ll learn to create the DRC Red Pine Granny Square, a textured motif ideal for building a blanket or using it alone as a coaster. This session emphasizes tactile learning, guiding you through the rhythmic and meditative motions of working with yarn and hooks.  Whether you’re a complete novice or an experienced maker, you’ll enjoy the satisfaction of creating something tangible. All materials are provided; just bring your curiosity and prepare to leave with a project you made yourself!
data.location: Kathleen W. Ludwig Global Village Living Learning Center
data.name: Learn to Crochet II: The DRC Red Pine Granny Square

data.description: Join the Center for Women in the Arts at Douglass for a workshop led by acclaimed artist Liz Collins! This unique needlepoint workshop invites you to explore the meditative joy of stitching. Collins will guide participants through the myriad of stitches possible within needlepoint and share her distinctive methodology for creating improvisational designs, treating needlepoint as a slow drawing process in response to the grid.   Only open to Douglass and Art & Design students. Free supplies and snacks provided! Supplies are limited – First come, first served. All skill levels and forms of stitching are welcome and supported. This experience counts towards the Douglass Discovery curriculum requirement. R3: Career/Discovery/Professional Development/Research. Reminder: To receive DRC curriculum credit, you must complete a reflection survey. *Liz Collins is the 2025-2026 Estelle Lebowitz & Ann Beneduce-Lebowitz Artist-in-Residence. Her solo exhibition, Shapeshifter, is on view through March 13, 2026 in the Mary H. Dana Women Artists Series Galleries at Douglass Libraries. ___ * Image and Media ReleaseBy attending this event, you acknowledge and agree that Rutgers University may photograph, record, or otherwise capture your artwork, image, and/or voice. You grant Rutgers the unrestricted right to use, reproduce, publish, and distribute these sound, still, or moving images in any medium for educational, promotional, advertising, or other purposes aligned with the University’s mission. All rights to these materials will belong to Rutgers University. Please let our photographer or videographer know if you do not want your image taken at the event.
data.name: Needlepoint Workshop with artist Liz Collins
data.organizationName: Academic Programs at Douglass Residential College - DRC

data.description: What does it mean to survive—intellectually, politically, ecologically, or aesthetically—in a moment defined by crisis? When uncertainty and chaos prevail, those who endure must bend, not break. They must adapt, redirect, stay fluid. How do figures of water help us think survival not as a static state but as a process: precarious, contingent, always at risk of being swept under? Survival and water: two conceptual forces that converge in literary, philosophical, and political discourses across the German tradition. Whether in the form of biblical floods, rising oceans, or mythic rivers—water stages a sight of duality: It is where life and death, healing and destruction, calmness and acceleration are able to meet in a resistant stream of becoming. To survive—especially “with one’s head above water”—is to inhabit the threshold between endurance and submersion, grasping for breath, clarity, meaning. At the same time, survival carries its own paradoxes: Who survives and at what cost? What kinds of knowledge or expression survive catastrophe, exile, war, or erasure—and which are drowned out? Water leaks across genres and disciplines: as metaphor for time and memory, as site of passage and peril, as resource and threat, as a medium of cleansing, forgetting, or border-policing. Meanwhile, survival speaks equally to historical trauma and everyday precarity, to climate catastrophe and cultural memory, to the bodies that wash ashore and those that remain submerged in the archive. This conference seeks contributions that take up the dual themes of survival and water—literally, figuratively, or formally—as critical frameworks. We welcome engagements with water as metaphor, medium, matter, and menace, and with survival as a philosophical problem, a narrative form, or a historical condition. What does it mean to be in over one’s head—psychically, politically, or ecologically? How might “keeping one’s head above water” register both resistance and exhaustion? How are the concepts of water and survival marshaled by thinkers, writers, artists, or regimes? How do literature, film, and theory reckon with flood, immersion, drowning, or breath? What kinds of bodies are asked to stay afloat, and at what cost? Brief: how do we keep our head above water; how do we survive the current?
data.name: HEAD ABOVE WATER: Surviving the Current. Rutgers German Graduate Student Conference
data.organizationName: German GSO (Graduate Organization)

data.description: Drop-in for an Artful Saturday monthly event hosted by the Center for the Women in the Arts at Douglass and Scarlet Arts RX! In this Women's History Month themed workshop, let your imagination take shape and make a mini rage piñata. Artsy door prizes! Bring a friend! Taught by a Scarlet Arts Rx student teaching artist from Rutgers Mason Gross School of the Arts. Free supplies, snacks, and boba provided! Supplies are limited – First come, first served. All skill levels and walk-ins welcome!  This experience counts towards the Douglass Discovery curriculum requirement. R3: Career/Discovery/Professional Development/Research. This event is part of the Douglass' 2026 Week of the Woman Series. Week of the Woman is a dedicated series that honors women’s impact and advances women’s leadership through community-engaged programs that inspire, educate, and mobilize Douglass students. Co-sponsored by the Douglass Community Engagement office.Reminder: To receive DRC curriculum credit, you must complete a reflection survey. ___ * Image and Media Release By attending this event, you acknowledge and agree that Rutgers University may photograph, record, or otherwise capture your artwork, image, and/or voice.
